pros: Valued based organisation you feel you can make a real difference to peoples lives.
cons: As it is a England wide organisation you can sometimes feel isolated

review_title: Not worth getting out of bed for
job_title: Peer Support Worker in Southend-on-Sea, England
pros: Helping the residents that are there for recovery
cons: Management Area managers Low low pay No incentives No progression Over workers, under paid Zero support from management. Blame, blame, blame Managers not present, always working from home. Never available. Let's residents do whatever they want and make their staff look incompetent when they are following policy guidelines. Let people remain in the job even when money has gone missing, showing up drunk to work, unable to carry out the simplest tasks, let after staff pick up the pieces. I can't stress enough the lack of support from management. Unable to fulfil the contract because they can't keep staff because it's so awful. They need to lose the Southend contract. Meant to have 7 recovery workers, only had 4 permanent when I went and making them 4 pick up all the shifts. 26hour long shifts. Rota only done one week at a time so no work life balance.

pros: Experience of working with service users of varied background and experience. A real privilege. Working with staff that (were) experienced and passionate for the job role for the benefit of the service users.
cons: Company doesn’t really care for the staff or service user experience. More focused on business aspects of health care rather than actual health or social care. An enormous amount of admin procedures which take up more time than you can actually spend with service users. Poor response or care for complaints or whistleblowing from staff. Higher management seems more interested in keeping the company looking superficially good rather than caring for the actual welfare and wellbeing of the employees, specifically if that involves complaints surrounding bullying from other staff. No progression. Poor pay considering risk.

pros: The opportunity to work with a diverse group of residents each with their own skills, interests and ambitions.
cons: - Terrible, below-sector average salary. - Lack of staff accountability, often compounded by staff shortages. - Poor hiring practices. - Poor enforcement of/adherence to organisational policy. - Lack of leadership from management. - Overall, inefficient and poorly thought out systems that ultimately result in vulnerable people not receiving the treatment and care that they deserve.

pros: They were very flexible around my schedule, and the pay was always on time and accurate.
cons: They cut our salary out of nowhere and expected us to stay.

pros: Staff (some of them) are good, and make life slightly easier
cons: The list is endless, bullying, makes out like they are a carrying organisation when in reality they are not. Incompetent payroll and HR. Unable to pay staff properly. Aggressive and poor management. People are promoted into management position but yet have no idea how to manage No facility for career development The pay is shockingly bad. Terrible given that RF is not a 'poor' organisation 0 stars

job_title: Mental Health Support Worker in Chichester, England
pros: My manager cared greatly about my mental well being and other co workers above else. My co workers in peer support looked out for me and made me feel welcomed and loved. Didn't have to stress about being late or missing days due to bad mental or physical health.
cons: Can be stressful at times when it comes to people you support. Some of the training is slightly out of date with the fact it uses less inclusive wording.

job_title: Mental Health Recovery Worker in Manchester, England
pros: - Enjoyed working with some colleagues - Enjoyed working with the clients and support those who needed help - Management were quite accommodating with shift changes but only when they had enough staff employed
cons: - No support (emotional or otherwise) from Management - Very little training, e-learning only - I worked at a service that should have been double staffed but I lone worked 60% of the time. Very lonely work - No ongoing advice or feedback (hardly any interaction at all with management) - Management could be very rude and dismissive - Very little effort went into replacing staff who had left, leaving long periods of being short staffed - Management didn't appear to have any compassion for the clients, despite having previously worked as a support worker. All they saw were rooms that had to be filled and little else

cons: - high staff turnover - the pay is atrocious

Work with some good people

One rule for one member of staff, one for everyone else.

Unsocial hours. One shift pattern is 2-10pm sleep (10hrs but with residents disturbing you) then working 8-4pm the next day...26 hours!!!!!

pros:

review_title: Strong ethos and values, echoed in solid people, coproduction is genuine not tokenistic
pros: Generally attracts caring people; the training is AMAZING - varied, specialised, interesting; my manager was supportive; lots of freedom to be creative and really own your work, I didn't feel micromanaged but supported to implement my new ideas and initiatives. Most of all, the values of hope, respect, belief etc are strongly there in the day to day work amongst the difficult climate of working in 2019 social care.
cons: Pay - but I'd rather be paid a bit less for a job I love.

pros: I have found the support so far in accessing additional support via eap very helpful.  All my line managers have been in touch with me offering me support and checking out how I could be furthered support as well as encouraging myself and other employees to access the EAP
cons: I work remotely and have had a number of IT issues.  The delay is often caused having to spend often 20 mins + on the telephone to montel.  Do not like the IT support that is in place but then I don't like IT when it goes wrong.

review_title: Unmotivated staff providing a bare minimum service

It is usual to find a 'jobsworth' attitude here, and it shows in the quality of service we give. Our lone working arrangements do not work reliably, which is a safety concern for staff.

RF are willing to listen to new ideas and look to move forward as a company.

review_title: All show and no substance.. not anymore, sadly.....
job_title: Mental Health Recovery Worker in London, England
pros: Good colleagues, very supportive line manager (has left - was made redundant and then got her position offered back to her to lower pay and with more responsibilities, she cried when she had to tell the team she is leaving and why) was very good, at the beginning this charity seemed alright and actually was a charity, at the beginning of my time of working there (2010) it actually felt like that we were able to have some positive impact on people - now they only seem to be greedy and grind their employees to the bone while actually expanding as an organisation.
cons:
Over the time this organisation has gone downhill. They have been much better employers at my beginning time (2010) but overtime they drastically stopped investing in their employees, extremely long shifts, management is not listening to workers, discussions about wellbeing of employees are a farce, antisocial behaviour of clients would be accepted, employees and other living in clients would not be protected. 
All of this while this organisation as a whole has actually EXPANDED and they are buying other charities.

My advice to the management: Read all of the above and please have a massive rethink about the purpose of this charity. Times might be harsh in a climate of cuts after cuts after cuts in the mental health sector - but instead of focusing on expansion and investing in a really good marketing department which is actually able to make you look so convincingly likeable and caring - instead of that please go back a lot of steps and think about your ethics and the quality you are providing: for people who use your services as well as all your employees. Please stop throwing around all these good sounding terms such as "co-working" between employees and "people who use the services" and go on about how we're all having an equal "big conversation". If anything has been working out at your services it is because the people who are working for you directly with the service users are giving their all and everything and actually care while still getting low wages and not being taken care of very well. Before this place turned into this chaotic state there were actually success stories of people who were able to benefit and develop which is so sad. Now I don't believe that anyone in the decision making ranks of management do give a damn about ethics. My last 2,5 years have been frustrating and in the long run soul-destroying and it took a toll  on me.

review_title: An organisation that encourages bullying and discrimination
job_title: Employment Adviser in Farnborough, Hampshire, South East England, England
pros: Dedicated employment advisors who, despite being unsupported by managers, are completely dedicated to supporting their clients. As the employment advisers are experiencing continuous bullying from their line managers plus micro-management they have lots of empathy for their clients.
cons:
I was employed on a new contract with the North East Hampshire and Farnham CCG to work with the IAPT provider Talkplus. We were based in the Farnborough Talkplus office.

I approached a senior manager for help and advice about the concerns I had for a team member. However, I was never contacted again to discuss these concerns and instead I was targeted for direct bullying. I left the organisation even though I did not have a new job as I was so concerned when the bullying began to involve vulnerable clients and I could not have this my conscious. I was shocked that this could happen and was allowed to happen. I was asked by an area manager to submit in writing my concerns. My grievance was acknowledged by the CEO, however, I was never contacted again and my concerns were not investigated by the Richmond Fellowship

This is not just one incompetent area of an organisation it is a culture that stems through the chain of responsibility.

After years working professionally in London, I chose to take a pay cut and work for the Richmond Fellowship where I could help people but I have been horrified at how they choose to treat their employees and by extension their vulnerable clients. I have never experienced a workforce so scared about raising concerns and this level of lying. The extent that the organisation is prepared to go to in order to cover up bad behaviour and bullying is scary.

I would not recommend working for this employer if you have a disability. Also, I cannot recommend this charity for anyone with empathy who genuinely cares because you will either be bullied or you will be victimised for raising concerns when you witness the bullying.
